sections.title: Demetrius and Alexander Compete for Jonathan’s Support
The Fall of Demetrius and New Alliances

verses.text: In the one hundred sixtieth year, Alexander Epiphanes, son of Antiochus, arrived and took possession of Ptolemais. The people there welcomed him, and he began his rule in that city.
verses.comment: The events here mark the beginning of Alexander Balas's rise in the Seleucid empire, with the year reckoned from the Seleucid dating system.

verses.text: When King Demetrius heard about this, he gathered a very large army and set out to confront Alexander in battle.
verses.comment: The rivalry between Demetrius I Soter and Alexander Balas set the stage for significant changes in Judean politics.

verses.text: Demetrius sent a letter to Jonathan, filled with peaceful and respectful words, hoping to honor him.
verses.comment: Demetrius seeks to win Jonathan's allegiance with promises of peace, seeing his strategic importance.

verses.text: For Demetrius thought, 'Let me move first to make peace with him before he joins Alexander against us.'
verses.comment: This verse reveals Demetrius's strategic reasoning, hoping to secure Jonathan's loyalty in case of war.

verses.text: He reasoned, 'Jonathan will surely remember all the harm we did to him, his brothers, and his nation.'
verses.comment: Demetrius recognizes Jonathan's grievances due to previous hostilities between the Seleucid rulers and the Jews.

verses.text: So Demetrius authorized Jonathan to gather troops, arm them with weapons, and be his ally. He also ordered that the hostages held in the citadel be released to Jonathan.
verses.comment: Granting Jonathan these powers and releasing the hostages would strengthen his position among the Jews.

verses.text: Jonathan came to Jerusalem and read the letter publicly to all the people and those stationed in the citadel.
verses.comment: Reading the letter aloud demonstrated the king’s favor and rallied public support for Jonathan.

verses.text: Hearing that the king had empowered Jonathan to recruit soldiers deeply disturbed those in the citadel.
verses.comment: Those occupying the citadel felt threatened by Jonathan’s increasing influence and military authority.

verses.text: Nonetheless, the residents of the citadel freed the hostages and handed them over to Jonathan, who then returned them to their families.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s care for the hostages increased his popularity and showed his commitment to the people.

verses.text: Jonathan settled in Jerusalem and began reconstructing and repairing the city.
verses.comment: Rebuilding Jerusalem symbolized a renewal of Jewish life and self-governance.

verses.text: He directed the workers to reinforce the city walls, surrounding Mount Zion with dressed stones for better defense. The people carried out his orders.
verses.comment: Restoring Jerusalem’s fortifications was crucial for its security against foreign control.

verses.text: Foreigners occupying the strongholds that Bacchides had built fled before Jonathan’s strength.
verses.comment: With Bacchides gone, many non-Jewish forces withdrew from Judean fortresses.

verses.text: They abandoned their posts and went back to their own lands.
verses.comment: The mass departure of Gentile forces reduced direct foreign control over Judean territory.

verses.text: Only a few remained in Beth-zur, men who had abandoned the law and commandments, because that city served as their safe haven.
verses.comment: Beth-zur functioned as a base for Jewish apostates who sided with foreign rulers.

verses.text: When King Alexander learned of all the promises Demetrius had made to Jonathan, and about the battles and courageous deeds Jonathan and his brothers had achieved, and their hardships,
verses.comment: Alexander takes notice of Jonathan’s military record and the lavish offers from Demetrius.

verses.text: he said, 'Where will we find another man like him? Let’s make him our friend and ally.'
verses.comment: Alexander aims to outbid Demetrius and secure Jonathan's loyalty for his cause.

verses.text: So Alexander wrote Jonathan a letter, which read as follows:
verses.comment: Direct royal correspondence was an extraordinary honor.

verses.text: "King Alexander greets his brother Jonathan.
verses.comment: Calling Jonathan 'brother' reflects a diplomatic gesture, signaling equality and alliance.

verses.text: We have heard reports of your strength and valor, and that you are worthy to be our friend.
verses.comment: Alexander acknowledges Jonathan's reputation, enticing him to his side.

verses.text: So today, we appoint you high priest of your nation, and name you ‘Friend of the King.’ Stand with us and remain in our good favor. We also send a purple robe and a golden crown as tokens of your office."
verses.comment: The high priesthood was conferred by foreign rulers as a political as well as religious position.

verses.text: In the seventh month of the one hundred sixtieth year, during the festival of booths, Jonathan donned the priestly garments, enlisted and armed many men.
verses.comment: By accepting the high priesthood and sacred vestments at Sukkot, Jonathan signaled a new legitimacy for the Hasmonean line.

verses.text: When Demetrius heard about these developments, he was troubled and said,
verses.comment: Demetrius realizes he has been outmaneuvered in his dealings with the Jews.

verses.text: "What have we done? Alexander has won favor with the Jews and allied with them to strengthen his position."
verses.comment: The political advantage gained by Alexander is apparent to Demetrius.

verses.text: So Demetrius reasoned, 'I too will send them encouraging words and promise them rewards, in hope they will support me.'
verses.comment: Demetrius’s bid to regain Jewish support comes from a place of political necessity.

verses.text: So he sent a message reading: A Letter from Demetrius to Jonathan "King Demetrius sends greetings to the Jewish people.
verses.comment: Demetrius directs his letter to the entire Jewish nation, not just to Jonathan.
verses.sectionHeader: Demetrius and Alexander Compete for Jonathan’s Support

verses.text: We have learned that you have remained loyal to us, kept your covenant, and not joined our enemies. This news has brought us joy.
verses.comment: Demetrius praises Jewish faithfulness, attempting to strengthen ties.

verses.text: If you continue in your loyalty, we will show you goodness in return for all you do for us.
verses.comment: Promises of future rewards were ways of securing ongoing allegiance.

verses.text: We will grant you significant exemptions and provide you with gifts.
verses.comment: The king offers incentives to ensure the Jews’ cooperation.

verses.text: "From now on, all Jews are released from tribute payments, salt taxes, and crown levies.
verses.comment: These taxes were burdensome, so their remission represented a significant benefit.

verses.text: And instead of receiving a third of their grain and half the fruit from trees, which used to be due to the crown, I now discharge these obligations for Judah and the three districts added to it from Samaria and Galilee, now and forever.
verses.comment: Fiscal independence for these territories would have empowered the Jewish state.

verses.text: Jerusalem and its territory, with their tithes and revenues, shall be holy and exempt from all taxation.
verses.comment: Designating Jerusalem as sacred and tax-free honored the religious heart of the nation.

verses.text: I also remove my control over the citadel of Jerusalem, giving it to the high priest to garrison with men of his choosing.
verses.comment: Returning control of the fortress was a symbolic and practical transfer of power.

verses.text: Every Jew taken as a captive from Judah into any area of my kingdom is now set free without cost, and officials must cancel any taxes owed on their livestock.
verses.comment: Freeing Jewish captives and suspending animal taxes would relieve burdens from the community.

verses.text: All festivals, sabbaths, new moons, appointed holy days, and also the three days both before and after a festival, are hereby declared days of exemption and rest for all Jews living throughout my kingdom.
verses.comment: These exemptions protected Jewish religious observance from secular interference.

verses.text: No one shall have the authority to demand anything from any Jew or trouble them on any matter on these days.
verses.comment: Legal exemption from official harassment preserved Sabbath observance and festal rest.

verses.text: Jews may be registered for royal service, up to thirty thousand men, who are to be given all the provisions supplied to the king’s own forces.
verses.comment: Allowing Jews into the military was both a privilege and a responsibility.

verses.text: Some shall be stationed in the king's strongest fortresses and hold high positions in the kingdom. Their leaders must be from their own people, and they are to live according to their ancestral laws, just as the king has commanded for Judah.
verses.comment: Self-rule and Jewish officers ensured religious autonomy even within the army.

verses.text: As for the three regions annexed to Judah from Samaria, let them be counted as part of Judah. They are to have one governor and obey the high priest alone.
verses.comment: The unification of these territories under the high priest expanded Jewish self-governance.

verses.text: Ptolemais and the territory around it I give to the temple in Jerusalem as a perpetual gift, to defray its annual expenses.
verses.comment: Assigning lands for the temple provided ongoing support for worship and sacrifices.

verses.text: Each year, I grant fifteen thousand silver shekels from the royal treasury, drawn from appropriate revenues.
verses.comment: Financial support from the crown increased the prestige and function of the temple.

verses.text: All outstanding amounts that government officials have not previously paid shall now be given for temple service.
verses.comment: This ensured that no state debts shortchanged temple operations.

verses.text: As for the five thousand silver shekels collected annually from temple revenues, this is also canceled, for it rightly belongs to the priests who serve there.
verses.comment: Remitting this royal tax strengthened temple finances for sacred duties.

verses.text: Anyone seeking sanctuary at the Jerusalem temple because of debt or royal obligation is herewith pardoned and will regain all his property throughout my realm.
verses.comment: Granting asylum at the temple was a protection for debtors and supported the sanctuary's status.

verses.text: The rebuilding and restoration of the temple’s structures shall be paid from the revenues of the king.
verses.comment: Royal funds contributed to the physical renewal of Jerusalem’s sanctuary.

verses.text: And the costs for reconstructing and fortifying the walls of Jerusalem and the rest of Judea shall likewise be paid from the king’s treasury."
verses.comment: State funding for these defenses showed official support for Jerusalem’s autonomy.

verses.text: However, when Jonathan and the people heard these promises, they did not trust or accept them, remembering all the harm Demetrius had caused Israel and how much he had oppressed them.
verses.comment: There is enduring suspicion toward Demetrius because of past betrayals.

verses.text: They chose to remain loyal to Alexander, for he had first dealt with them kindly, and they continued as his allies throughout his reign.
verses.comment: The people’s loyalty was secured by prior positive dealings with Alexander.

verses.text: King Alexander assembled a massive force and set up camp opposite Demetrius.
verses.comment: A major confrontation between the rival kings was imminent.
verses.sectionHeader: The Fall of Demetrius and New Alliances

verses.text: The two kings engaged in battle, but Demetrius's army was routed; Alexander pursued them and defeated them thoroughly.
verses.comment: This decisive victory shifted the balance of power in the region.

verses.text: Alexander pressed the fight until the sun went down, and on that day Demetrius lost his life.
verses.comment: With Demetrius' death, the path was open for Alexander to claim the Seleucid throne.

verses.text: Afterward, Alexander sent envoys to Ptolemy, king of Egypt, with this message:
verses.comment: Seeking an alliance by marriage was a common diplomatic strategy.

verses.text: "Now that I have returned to my kingdom and taken the throne of my ancestors, with the realm secure—since I have defeated Demetrius and reclaimed our land—
verses.comment: Alexander asserts his legitimacy and frames his kingdom as restored.

verses.text: for I challenged him in battle and his army was crushed by us, and I now rule as king over his realm—
verses.comment: Victory in battle marked the transfer of royal authority.

verses.text: let us therefore unite in friendship. Give me your daughter as a wife, so I may be your son-in-law; I will send worthy gifts to both you and her, fitting for your status."
verses.comment: Marriage alliances were tools for consolidating kingdoms and sealing treaties.

verses.text: King Ptolemy replied, 'A joyful day indeed, when you returned to the land of your ancestors and ascended to their throne.
verses.comment: Ptolemy expresses diplomatic delight to encourage the alliance.

verses.text: And now, I shall do just as you have asked. Meet me at Ptolemais, and we will see each other face to face. I will receive you as my son-in-law, as you have proposed.'
verses.comment: Ptolemy consents to the marital union, supporting Alexander’s kingship.

verses.text: So Ptolemy journeyed from Egypt with his daughter Cleopatra to Ptolemais, in the one hundred sixty-second year.
verses.comment: The rendezvous at Ptolemais marked a significant royal alliance.

verses.text: King Alexander came to meet them, and Ptolemy gave him his daughter Cleopatra in marriage, celebrating the wedding at Ptolemais with splendor befitting kings.
verses.comment: This union strengthened Alexander’s ties with Egypt and increased his legitimacy.

verses.text: Then King Alexander wrote to Jonathan inviting him to visit.
verses.comment: Jonathan's loyalty was rewarded with royal recognition.

verses.text: So Jonathan went with much honor to Ptolemais, where he met both kings. He presented rich gifts of silver, gold, and other treasures, and gained great favor with them.
verses.comment: Gift-giving emphasized diplomacy and sealed alliances.

verses.text: However, a group of troublemakers from Israel, apostates, gathered to accuse Jonathan, but the king paid them no mind.
verses.comment: The king ignored the complaints, demonstrating his trust in Jonathan.

verses.text: Instead, the king ordered Jonathan’s ordinary clothes to be removed and had him dressed in purple; this was done at once.
verses.comment: Being clothed in purple was a visible sign of royal favor and status.

verses.text: The king had him seated at his side, and commanded his officials, 'Go out with him into the center of the city and proclaim that no one may bring any charge against him or trouble him for any reason.'
verses.comment: This public declaration protected Jonathan from false accusations and increased his honor.

verses.text: When his opponents saw the public recognition and purple robe, they fled in fear.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s enemies were silenced and scattered by the king’s explicit support.

verses.text: Thus, Jonathan was honored by the king, made one of his chief Friends, and appointed as general and governor of the province.
verses.comment: These titles and offices marked the peak of Jonathan’s political rise.

verses.text: Jonathan returned to Jerusalem, rejoicing and at peace.
verses.comment: Returning safely symbolized the favor and security Jonathan now enjoyed.

verses.text: In the one hundred sixty-fifth year, Demetrius, son of Demetrius, arrived from Crete to the land of his ancestors.
verses.comment: A new Demetrius II emerges as a contender for the throne.

verses.text: When King Alexander heard of this, he was greatly troubled and returned to Antioch.
verses.comment: Alexander perceived the threat and retreated to secure his power base.

verses.text: Meanwhile, Demetrius appointed Apollonius as governor over Coelesyria, who gathered a large force and camped near Jamnia. Then he sent this message to Jonathan the high priest:
verses.comment: Apollonius served as a leading general under Demetrius II, challenging Jonathan’s authority.

verses.text: "You are the only one resisting us, and because of you, I have been disgraced and mocked. Why have you claimed power in the hill country?
verses.comment: Apollonius challenges Jonathan’s boldness and authority over Judea.

verses.text: If you trust in your army, come down to the plain, and let us fight there, for I command the strength of the cities.
verses.comment: He taunts Jonathan, urging him to meet on terrain favorable to the Seleucid cavalry.

verses.text: Ask around to learn who I am and who supports me. People will tell you that you cannot stand against us, since your ancestors were twice defeated in their own land.
verses.comment: He mocks Jonathan, alluding to previous Jewish defeats.

verses.text: This time, you will not withstand my cavalry and the might of my army in the open plain, where there are no stones or refuge.
verses.comment: The open plain favored Seleucid military tactics, especially cavalry charges.

verses.text: When Jonathan heard Apollonius’s words, his spirit was stirred. He chose ten thousand troops and marched out from Jerusalem, joined by his brother Simon.
verses.comment: Jonathan rallies Jewish forces for a decisive confrontation.

verses.text: He camped before Joppa, but the city’s gates were closed, since Apollonius had stationed a garrison there.
verses.comment: Joppa’s strategic port resisted Jonathan’s advance due to Seleucid fortifications.

verses.text: So Jonathan attacked the city, and the inhabitants, in fear, surrendered and opened the gates, giving him control over Joppa.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s reputation and might enabled him to capture Joppa without excessive violence.

verses.text: When Apollonius heard of this, he mustered three thousand cavalry and a large force, moving towards Azotus, pretending to continue onward, but actually advancing into the plain, confident in his cavalry.
verses.comment: Apollonius uses tactical maneuvering to lure Jonathan into a pitched battle.

verses.text: Jonathan pursued Apollonius toward Azotus, and both sides prepared to meet in battle.
verses.comment: The battle at Azotus would be a major test for Jonathan’s military leadership.

verses.text: Meanwhile, Apollonius had secretly stationed a thousand cavalry in ambush behind Jonathan’s force.
verses.comment: Ambushes and surprise attacks were common Seleucid battle tactics.

verses.text: Jonathan realized there was an ambush to his rear; they were surrounded and attacked with arrows from morning until late afternoon.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s awareness of battlefield tactics enabled him to withstand an encirclement.

verses.text: But Jonathan’s men held firm, following his commands, and eventually the enemy horses tired.
verses.comment: Discipline and resilience prevailed over the Seleucid cavalry’s initial advantage.

verses.text: Simon then advanced his own troops, attacked the phalanx, overwhelming them so they fled in panic.
verses.comment: Simon's intervention turned the tide against the enemy’s formation.

verses.text: The cavalry scattered across the plain, fleeing to Azotus and seeking refuge in Beth-dagon, the temple of their idol.
verses.comment: Seeking sanctuary in a pagan temple highlighted the enemy’s desperation.

verses.text: Jonathan set fire to Azotus and the towns around it, looting them; the temple of Dagon and those who hid inside were also burned.
verses.comment: The destruction of Dagon’s temple echoed earlier biblical episodes of idol judgment.

verses.text: Those slain by the sword, together with those burned inside, totaled about eight thousand.
verses.comment: The large casualty count emphasized the magnitude of Jonathan’s victory.

verses.text: Jonathan then marched to Askalon, where the citizens came out to greet him with great ceremony.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s military successes earned him widespread respect in the region.

verses.text: He and his men returned to Jerusalem, carrying away great spoils.
verses.comment: Bringing back the booty signaled both victory and God’s blessing.

verses.text: Upon learning of these events, King Alexander honored Jonathan further,
verses.comment: Jonathan’s achievements secured even greater royal favor.

verses.text: sending him a golden brooch—the custom for the King’s Kinsmen—and gifted him Ekron and its surrounding territory as his possession.
verses.comment: Receiving Ekron as a private estate symbolized administrative authority and personal reward.
